body: James McMullan's signature is just about everywhere again. It's in New York City subway stations from Riverdale to Brooklyn Heights. It's on Amtrak platforms from Philadelphia to Boston. It's in ticket-brokers' offices and in dozens of newspaper advertisements. And it adorns the cover of the Playbill for "Two Shakespearean Actors," the Lincoln
title: Capturing the Essence of a Play For Lincoln Center's Posters

body: Sharks' Senses Q. Does a shark really smell blood from a long way away in the water? A. "Definitely," said Louis Garibaldi, director of the New York Aquarium at Coney Island, Brooklyn. "Sharks have an extremely sensitive sense of smell for blood in the water." A few molecules can be enough to draw a shark. A shark has nostrils, called nares,
title: Q&A

body: Sybil Hart Kooper, a retired justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in New York, died on Wednesday at her home in Brooklyn Heights. She was 66 years old. She died of breast cancer, a former aide said. It was because of the cancer that she retired on Oct. 31 from the Second Judicial Department of the Appellate Division. The
title: Sybil Kooper, 66, Former Justice In New York Appellate Division

body: Jack Tannen, a retired antiquarian bookseller whose lower Manhattan emporium was a mecca for book lovers, died early Tuesday in Memorial Hospital in Hollywood, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in Hollywood. The cause of his death was not clear but was probably heart failure, his family said. For half a century Mr. Tannen was in partnership with
title: Jack Tannen, 84, Whose Shop Of Old Books Was a Rarity, Too

body: Allan M. Schneider, a real-estate broker on eastern Long Island, died on Friday at a friend's house in East Hampton. He was 54 years old and lived in East Hampton. title: Allan Schneider, 54, L.I. Real-Estate Broker

title: Social Events

body: Food From Afar One of the year's more engaging cookbooks, "The Ellis Island Immigrant Cookbook," did not come off the slick presses of a big publishing house but grew from two years of loving effort by Tom Bernardin, who compiled and published it himself. Mr. Bernardin, an entrepreneur and a former English teacher, worked as a guide at the Statue
title: Food Notes

title: Holiday Events Abound in the City

title: John N. LaCorte, 81, Champion of Italians and Columbus Day

body: Buffeted by the recession and humbled somewhat by the mixed results of its ambitious innovations of the last decade, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is pulling back. It is no longer planning the incinerators, industrial parks and other economic development projects that occupied it in the 80's. The huge agency -- the largest, most
title: In Eye of Economic Storm, the Port Authority Battens Down

body: IN a new effort to stem sliding sales of German wines in the United States, six major German producers have turned to smaller bottles in hopes of appealing to American's concerns about health. The producers have shipped to the East Coast seven white wines from the highly touted 1990 vintage in 500-milliliter bottles. These bottles hold nearly 17
title: Germans Decrease Bottle Size For Wine

body: For years, Diane Ravitch dismissed the kind of Potomac lures that have attracted scholars from Henry Kissinger to Arthur Schlesinger Jr. to public service. "I didn't want to work in government ever," Ms. Ravitch said. "I thought that if I wanted a government job that it would corrupt me." Now she has not one Washington job, but two: Assistant
title: Washington at Work; Education Scholar Finds Delight as Federal Official

body: The Transit Authority, whose repeated attempts to replace hundreds of aging exhaust fans in its subway tunnels have been riddled with problems, said yesterday that it spent about $1 million last year rebuilding eight large fans that, it later realized, were too powerful to be turned on. Four of the fans, designed to pump smoke out of tunnels in
title: Subway Tunnel Fans Are Rebuilt but All Wrong

body: Some of the most congested parts of Brooklyn can expect "nightmarish traffic" virtually until the end of the century, transportation officials said yesterday, as reconstruction continues on the Brooklyn Bridge and work has begun on the Gowanus Expressway. A new chapter in the long, bad dream starts at noon tomorrow -- and will last until 6 A.M.
title: Driving in Brooklyn? Expect the Worst

body: The four plays in the 1991 Young Playwrights Festival have a diversity of styles and purposes but they are unified by the theme of denial and by a high caliber of performance. In each work, people refuse to accept an image of themselves that is either earned or imposed on them by outsiders. In several cases, the reaction is vociferous. Denial is
title: Review/Theater; For Four Young Playwrights, a World of Denial

body: Let's hear it for charitable pedestrians: thousands of them are expected to converge on Central Park and Battery Park this weekend and next. Their purpose: to raise money to help combat breast cancer and diabetes. Deputy Mayor BILL LYNCH is among those who plan to go through their paces Sunday in the 12-kilometer (7 1/2-mile) Walk for the Cure
title: CHRONICLE

body: AT once a densely and diversely populated chunk of New York and a complex tangle of stereotypes and myths, Brooklyn evokes many images to the world beyond its famous bridge. It's the Dodgers and "The Honeymooners," the faded, honky-tonk luster of Coney Island and the elegance of Brooklyn Heights, and, sadly, the violence and racial tensions now
title: The Brooklyn Cookbook: Mix Ethnic Attitudes and Memories

body: Lawrence I. List, a senior partner in the law firm of Carter, Ledyard & Milburn, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. He was 53 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights and Tolland, Mass. He died of complications from lung cancer, the family said. Mr. List graduated from Yale University in 1958 and from Harvard
title: Lawrence I. List, 53, A Real-Estate Lawyer

title: For Children

body: Summertime has its own rhythms, so time-honored that you can plan your life by them. You buy your swimsuit in June, you take it easy in July, you eat peaches in August. Just before Labor Day you buy a fall outfit or take care of those back-to-school purchases. And September is for cool days and apples. Not this year. Freakish weather, including the
title: Between Heat and Hurricane, Summer Weather Is Weird

body: When police officers investigating the slaying of a bartender at a Second Avenue pub late Thursday knocked on the door of a Brooklyn apartment yesterday, the man in the bathrobe who answered turned out to be an escaped murderer who was one of the city's most wanted fugitives. In the apartment, officers also found five guns, including a sawed-off
title: Escaped Killer Seized in Brooklyn, by Chance

body: SALES of houses, co-ops and condominiums in the New York metropolitan area, still near the bottom of a slump that has been longer and deeper than any since before World War II, have improved steadily since the spring in what analysts say is the beginning of a slow recovery. Throughout the region, real estate executives say sales volume surged in
title: After a Long Slump, Home Sales Rise

body: Beaux Arts Trio Avery Fisher Hall Because the Beaux Arts Trio is to play all of Mozart's Piano Trios (along with the Piano Quartets) in three concerts at Lincoln Center next year, it devoted most of its Mostly Mozart program on Monday evening to works by Beethoven and Dvorak. It did, however, offer a preview of its series in the form of Mozart's
title: Music in Review

body: A partial handprint found on an iron fence led to the arrest of a Queens man yesterday in the rape of an assistant district attorney in her Brooklyn Heights apartment last week, the police said. The suspect, 33-year-old Victor Hardy, has a record of at least 40 arrests, none of them for sex crimes, the authorities said. The police said Mr. Hardy,
title: Queens Man Held in Rape of Brooklyn Prosecutor

body: Three burned-out steel piers stand like eerily twisted skeletons in Upper New York Bay as teen-agers swim past the rusted shell of a half-submerged Chevy Cutlass off the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn. Just to the north, beyond the stench of the Gowanus Canal and a huge, unused grain terminal, a short-lived Port Authority project called Fishport
title: Development Not Even a Contender on Brooklyn's Waterfront

body: Bargemusic Fulton Ferry Landing Brooklyn Heights At a time when chamber music is typically heard in halls scaled for full orchestra performances, the concerts at Bargemusic are a reminder of the form's intimate roots. The series was started in 1977 by Olga Bloom, whose refurbished 92-year-old coffee barge on the East River seats about 130. The
title: Music in Review

body: Hussein Jaber, a Palestinian who moved from Jerusalem to Brooklyn 12 years ago, has creatively adapted himself to life in Sunset Park -- one of New York City's most ethnically diverse neighborhoods -- by hanging a sign in his bodega's window, which caters to the area's large Hispanic population, saying "Mexican grocery." A few blocks to the north,
title: Neighborhood Politics: Choosing the Council - An occasional look at the races for New York's new City Council; Varied Interests Vie to Represent Brooklyn District

body: James L. Hairston Jr. fell into bed at 8 A.M. on Thursday after driving an exhausting 12-hour shift in his cab the night before. He was awakened two hours later by a sharp authoritative knock at the door of his Brooklyn home. It was the police. "Put your clothes on; you're coming with us," Mr. Hairston said a husky detective with ice-blue eyes told
title: The Wrong Man In Wrong Photo Feels Wronged

body: Armed now with what they said was the right picture of the right man, the police announced yesterday that they had arrested a 22-year-old former security guard and charged him with two rapes in the Stuyvesant Park area of lower Manhattan. They said he was a suspect in a third. The man, Garry Jacques, was arrested at 2 A.M. yesterday outside his
title: Ex-Guard Is Charged in East Side Rapes

body: Alan J. Haber, the spokesman for the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission in the early 1980's, died yesterday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 34 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights. He died of pneumonia resulting from AIDS, his sister said. He was raised in Brooklyn and graduated from Hunter College. In the late
title: Alan Haber, 34, Dies; Landmarks Panel Aide

body: A Brooklyn assistant district attorney was raped in her apartment early yesterday by a man who climbed through a slightly open window and grabbed her as she came out of her bedroom, the police said. He put a pillow over her face, tied her hands with a telephone cord, raped her and then stole a number of items from her Brooklyn Heights apartment,
title: Assistant Prosecutor Raped In Her Brooklyn Apartment

body: International A3-13 The diplomacy over the hostages in the Middle East will go into a quiet period, according to the U.N. Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, while, presumably, his Iranian contacts seek to provide him with proof of what has happened to seven Israeli servicemen. Page A1 An Israeli wife struggles to balance hope and realism

title: Sports of The Times; Rooting To Stay Clean

title: St. Ann's Church

body: Philip Copp found himself in the unusual position of being above ground last Saturday. Normally, Saturdays find him prowling subway stations in search of beauty, history and few more paragraphs for his ever more endless opus. But there he was strolling down Joralemon Street in Brooklyn Heights, praising the Belgian cobblestones and tall shade
title: About New York

body: Would Henry James have described "summer afternoon" as the two most beautiful words in the English language if he had been in these parts yesterday? Ha! Not if he had been among the thousands of people who filed sullenly past the intersection of Broadway and 46th Street at 8 A.M. It was hazy, already sweltering and the billowing emission from a
title: Finish the Phrase, New York: Is It (Blank) Enough for You?

body: Bishop Francis J. Mugavero, who in his 22 years as the head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn combined staunch liberalism and a fierce loyalty to the Vatican, died yesterday at the age of 77. The Bishop, who retired in February 1990, died of a heart attack while vacationing in East Hampton, L.I., said Frank DeRosa, the spokesman for the
title: Francis J. Mugavero, 77, Is Dead; Was Bishop of Brooklyn 22 Years

body: An 18-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested late Friday night and charged with shooting an assistant district attorney in the back while robbing him at an automatic teller machine on Wednesday, the police said. The suspect, Kenneth Martinez, was arrested at his home, 234 Sands Street in Brooklyn Heights, at 11:45 P.M. Friday, said a police spokesman,
title: Man Held in Robbery of Assistant Prosecutor

body: A Short History of the American Revolution By James L. Stokesbury 304 pages. William Morrow. $23. Once a year on Independence Day, it's useful to recall that the United States was created by colonial revolutionaries who wanted to govern themselves and not be ruled by kings or their modern equivalents in various despotic corners of the world. Unlike
title: Books of The Times; A Revolution That Many Still Look To as a Beacon

body: In an attempt to create affordable housing that conforms to the historic architecture of its neighborhood, a consortium of builders is completing work on 19 three-story brick rowhouses in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Each building has only one apartment to a floor. And, like many 19th-century rowhouses and brownstones in Williamsburg, Fort
title: Postings: Joint Effort In Brooklyn; 19 Brick Rowhouses With Stoops

body: What a paradise Central Park can seem! Especially this summer, when the recession threatens New York City's cultural institutions. These activities -- especially the ones conducted by the Urban Park Rangers, whose numbers were
title: FOR CHILDREN

body: NEXT Sunday is the cutoff date for the New York City Council to establish new procedures for nonprofit owners of landmark buildings to appeal for relief because of financial hardship. Preservationists are nervously considering which buildings might be the first to bring a request for demolition under liberalized rules. One that always gets a second
title: Streetscapes: St. Ann's Church; An 1869 Work With a Shaky Future

body: On a hot summer day, Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn near Borough Hall feels like Los Angeles, with here and there a solitary stroller beside four lanes of traffic. Except for the occasional gas station or car wash, there is little sign of habitation, and with the architectural bleakness comes a sense of isolation. The sun beats down and there is no
title: Sunday Outing; 3 Antiques-Rich Blocks in Brooklyn

body: For some parade watchers yesterday, there was a lot of climbing. They climbed on top of grimy, boxy street-corner newsstands, even though the police told them not to. They climbed on top of soft-drink vendors' trucks, even though the vendors' bosses would have told them not to if the bosses had not climbed up there already. And they clambered out
title: NEW YORK SALUTES; Craning and Scrambling For a Glimpse of History

body: While New York City is still primarily a tenant's town, the surge of co-op conversions and housing construction in the 1980's brought the level of homeownership above 25 percent for the first time, according to figures in the 1990 census. It is a truism of American life that people who own their homes think and act differently from renters, and a
title: Homeownership At Record Level For New Yorkers

title: Postings: 11 of 'the Best'; Landmarks Citations

body: NO doubt about it: New York City was, is and always will be the big magnet that draws in the crowds. In spring, fall and winter, there's that unmistakable pull toward the in-town concert halls, theaters and art galleries. Summer is the time to reverse the field, to venture out from the city, to get away from the middle-of-the-night car alarms and
title: Outings; Where to Find Quiet Places Out of the City

body: Wynton Marsalis borrowed 12-year-old Sandy Carhuayano's homemade plywood guitar and proceeded to pluck the wires that served for strings. " Plong -- plong plong -- plong," he told the 110 fifth- and sixth-grade musicians assembled at Public School 8 in Brooklyn. "That's the rhythm I want to hear." title: For Marsalis, It's Strike Up the Class

The ceremony was held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. An honorary Doctorate of Laws was

body: DEAR Diary: Walking along Fifth Avenue the other day, I noticed that pedestrian traffic had all but come to a standstill. Instead of the usual mad lunchtime rush, pockets of people gathered along the sidewalks near 34th Street, craning their necks toward the Manhattan skyline. Outside the electronics stores that line the avenue, employees were
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: 1. THE feeding frenzy is over -- no great loss to people who don't want to make reservations three weeks in advance to dine at their favorite restaurant at a civilized hour. 2. There are exceptions to every rule. 3. New York still has some restaurants where the above does not apply: Lutece, Coco Pazzo, Bouley and the River Cafe, to name a few. Five
title: DE GUSTIBUS; Reserving a Table: Less Waiting, Except at Lutece or Bouley

body: IN its most substantive effort in a decade to protect the historic and architectural treasures of Harlem, the Landmarks Preservation Commission has proposed 25 structures in upper Manhattan for landmark designation. The first public hearing, which cranks up the designation process, is being planned for early July, and more may follow. If all 25
title: Landmarks: Now, It's Harlem's Turn

body: What does a furniture designer do with scrap wood? For several years, Stephen Piscuskas has used leftovers from his York Street Studio in Brooklyn Heights to build boxes as gifts for friends. They proved so popular he's now selling custom boxes and trays -- for jewelry, pencils, chess pieces, whatever -- in both blond tiger maple and marquetry
title: Style Makers; Stephen Piscuskas, Home Furnishings Designer

body: THIS being the month for yard sales, 2,000 families in two huge red-brick apartment complexes in the heart of Manhattan set up shop last weekend, planting card tables and blankets and bedspreads under the trees. O.K., they have no yards. But they do have lots of grass in the apartment complexes, Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, which are
title: Urban Yard Sale, Without the Yard

body: Tim Buckley Tribute Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity Brooklyn Heights Since his death in 1975 from a drug overdose, a cult has grown up around Tim Buckley, a folk-jazz singer and songwriter whose free-form compositions and fervent yowl suggested a hybrid of Van Morrison and Kenny Rankin skewed with avant-garde inclinations. title: Pop in Review

body: The Way to Pop "They say that whatever doesn't kill you makes you stronger," Michael Bolton said at his office in Manhattan last week. "That's what happened here." title: The Pop Life

title: Harlan Fiske Stone 2d, a Philatelist, Weds Helen Galatan, Legal Assistant

body: "We're working within our own company to develop personalities," Oliver Smith said intently, his long lean frame tucked into a chair in an office at American Ballet Theater headquarters, just north of Union Square. title: Oliver Smith's Vision Of Ballet Theater

body: Jessica Weber still sighs in amused disbelief when she recalls the occasion a year or so ago when she was interviewing housecleaners for her 1,850-square-foot loft in Greenwich Village. One of the contenders was just about to get the thumbs-up sign when she announced, "I forgot to tell you: I don't bend." She didn't get the job, but that very day
title: Yes, They Do Windows, Sometimes on Pointe

body: It's hard to believe, I know, but there are out-of-towners out there who don't sit around singing "I Love New York" day in and day out. They have this idea that if they visit New York City, all they will see is vandalized subway cars. I say, take them to the Transit Museum. This tribute to the city's 714-mile-long underworld is in Brooklyn Heights
title: OFFBEAT IDEAS TO AMUSE VISITORS; Transit Museum

body: Inscribed in bronze above the front doors of the Brooklyn Public Library's central library on Grand Army Plaza is the writer Roscoe C. E. Brown's idealistic paean to the printed word: "While men have wit to read and will to know, the door to learning is the open book." But as the library marks its 50th anniversary today, that door to learning is
title: Somber 50th Birthday for Brooklyn's Main Library

title: The Spoken Word

body: A huge religious complex is being built on a former dairy farm here as the training center of the Watchtower Bible and Tract Society, better known as the Jehovah's Witnesses. When completed, the 27-building campus, called the Patterson Farm, will be the major educational institution for the church's missionaries and staff, equipped to teach, house
title: Jehovah's Witnesses Build Center on Dairy Farm

body: A deaf man stabbed another deaf man to death and wounded a deaf couple early yesterday in a Brooklyn apartment, the police said. A police spokeswoman, Sgt. Tina S. title: Police Accuse Deaf Man of Killing Another

body: Half a mile of water separates the popular, slick and immensely profitable South Street Seaport from an abandoned and forbidding cluster of nine red-brick warehouses on the Brooklyn waterfront known as the Empire Stores. By the end of the decade, this huge complex of prime Brooklyn waterfront buildings could become a cultural and retail center as
title: Changing Warehouses Into a Cultural Center

title: Sacred Exaltation: Calendar of Music For Easter Season

body: REMEMBER the great moment in the movie "The Mouse That Roared," when a medieval-style warrior, named Tully Bascombe, sails into New York Harbor only to find the city totally empty: not a single stockbroker, secretary, police officer, tourist, hot-dog vendor, bicyclist, jogger or what we used to call a "bum" in sight? Best of all, no lawyers,
title: One on One With New York

body: A FIVE-YEAR campaign to lure office development to the New York City boroughs outside Manhattan is scoring scattered new successes but encountering tough resistance because of the city's real estate and business downturn. The program, called the "other boroughs" strategy during the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, has relied on an array of
title: 'Other Boroughs' Strategy Bucks Difficult Times

body: The "Parsifal" tradition at the Metropolitan Opera -- renewed this Thursday evening with a new production directed by Otto Schenk -- is both venerable and startling. It evokes America's heyday of German opera, when the Wagner cult reached Peoria. It also sheds light on Wagner's shifting function in our cultural affairs. Wagner nights once sold out
title: CLASSICAL MUSIC; Wagner's American Emissary

body: A sore foot cured Paula Friedman's broken heart. For more than half her life, the 58-year-old Russian emigre had hoped that one day she would be reunited with her cousin Boris, who fled their hometown, Gorky, in 1957 for Israel. Two years ago she herself left, for Brooklyn, with her hope as faded as the few photographs she had of the ruggedly
title: 34 Years and a Sore Foot Later, a Reunion

body: Responding to a highly critical internal report on the handling of a fatal subway-tunnel fire, officials of the New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that they would revamp rescue procedures and repair subway tracks wherever they are vulnerable to the kind of short circuit that started the fire. Transit officials said they would try to
title: Subway Officials Unveil New Fire-Safety Plans

body: As most of New York and the world careen toward the 21st century, in one rarefied corner of Brooklyn, the more genteel days of the late 19th century have yet to end. This was never more evident than on Monday night, when about 70 well-to-do men gathered in an elegant Brooklyn Heights home, much as they and their forebearers have done since the
title: In Brooklyn Heights, Wisps of Victorian Age

body: After the War A8-11 The U.S. does not expect initiatives to rise immediately from President Bush's call for Israel to give up occupied Arab lands in return for peace, but hopes to secure modest good-will gestures, officials said. Page A1 News analysis: Most of Israel agrees that there has never been a more opportune time for Israel to make peace
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: The rockabilly singer Sleepy LaBeef is something of an anachronism, not because of the music he plays but because of the way he plays it. Though most pop musicians today think of a live show as a complement to, or re-creation of, an album or studio recording, Mr. LaBeef, who has been performing for more than 35 years, prefers to present his music
title: POP/JAZZ; Sleepy LaBeef's Living History Lesson

body: A Transit Authority investigation into a fatal fire in a Brooklyn subway tunnel has found that train dispatchers initially focused their rescue efforts on the wrong trains, leaving the train in most jeopardy stalled in the tunnel, transit officials said yesterday. About 1,000 people were trapped for nearly 40 minutes in December on a smoke-filled
title: Inquiry Reports Rescue Mix-Up In Subway Fire

body: Kenneth Fisher, a 38-year-old lawyer, claimed victory last night in the special election in the 29th City Council District in Brooklyn. Mr. Fisher said unofficial election results indicated that he had won by nearly 1,100 votes. Official results are to be released by the Board of Elections on Friday. Mr. Fisher's strongest opponent in the
title: Brooklyn Lawyer Defeats 8 Rivals In Special Race for a Council Seat

body: On Tuesday, voters in the 29th City Council District in Brooklyn will choose from among nine candidates who have spent a total of $500,000 in a race for an office that will cease to exist before the end of the year. Most of the candidates are liberal Democrats with barely distinguishable positions, but no trace of traditional party affiliations can
title: 9-Way Race for a Seat Soon to Vanish

body: Most people concerned with New York City's historic districts focus on what goes on within them, and particularly on preserving the older buildings that give them their special character. But now what goes on just beyond the borders of the districts is to get some attention. "New York Historic Districts: Challenges at the Edge," is the topic of the
title: Postings: Historic District Discussion; Skirting the Edges

body: Tuesday's nonpartisan election to fill the City Council seat in Brooklyn's 29th District is important. The winner will have a clear advantage in the fall election when the Council expands to 51 members and comes into its own under the new City Charter. The tone of the campaign has been far from uplifting and makes a choice difficult. Nonetheless,
title: Joan Millman for City Council

body: Although Brooklyn's rich diversity of historic and architecturally distinct housing is far too much to be explored in a day, those interested in serious sampling may want to consider a bus tour being offered next Sunday by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. title: Postings: History and Housing; Touring Brooklyn by Bus

body: Robert Phillips, a pianist and composer, died on Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan. title: Robert Phillips, 57, Part of Piano Duo

body: Teresa Tymoski, a vice president of Henri Bendel, looked at a mohair chartreuse sweater the other day and nearly squealed in delight. title: Unknown Designers Parade Dreams Before Fashion Arbiters at 'Open-See'

He promised that the Transit Authority would contact the riders after the completion of a toxicological analysis to determine the
title: Riders May Have Breathed Toxic Fumes in Brooklyn Subway Fire

body: THE crisis in the Persian Gulf has brought an unexpected bonanza to one group in the New York area: the International Sand Collectors Society. As the television cameras pan over the Saudi horizon, its members feast on images of the stuff that most people would regard as a paler, more organized form of dirt. Theirs is by no means the oddest
title: Sand? Birds? Rock? Clubs for All Tastes

body: TIRED of standing in line to see Mexican at the Met? Weary of looking high and low at the Museum of Modern Art? title: Halls of History, Fame, Oddity and Wonder

body: New York City officials, drawing lessons from last week's fatal subway fire, recommended a series of steps yesterday to avert similar disasters. The recommendations in a report prepared for Mayor David N. Dinkins included improved communications, better training and equipment for rescuers and closer cooperation between the Transit Authority and the
title: City Report on Subway Fire Urges Better Rescue Efforts
